Probub'y few people who visited the exhibition of leadlest glaze products just held in London ere aware of the preoedente whioh may be adduced from ant qnity for the g az ng -I pottery without resort to compounds of lead. The oldest as well aa the simplest of glsz a pure silioate of soda, The Egyptian potters nsed pure alkaline siliogtes wholly free from lead. Whether this was from ignoranoe i f the lead process ia nooertain ; but as the soil of Egypt is pertioolarly rich in alkali the omission, says the “Weatmioater G xe'te," probably dae to the abundance of a natural substitute more ready to band. The Assyrians, on the other hand, and the Persiajs rfcsr them, aaed lead. Of the Pbce lioian and Hallo-iio earthenwares, the earliest instances are un- glttad. Gradually the Greek potter* discovered he advantage of adding silioa and an alkali to the pigment employed, till they snoce ded in producing tba fine, thin, and completely leadless glszs whioh hu rarely been exoelli (L
It was cot, indeed, till the Middle Agee that lead became a customary ingredient in the glazing process. Both for artiatio pnrpo e« aud fur durability aud hardneae the leadless ware has the advantage; the sole recomm- dttioos cf leaded gLzs bring th) diminu im of porousness and tho decrease in the oc prodac’.ion. Q.-eater fusibility is secured when Oxide if lead is added, and the glszs can th is he applied to a day body which would no* stand the high temperature necsssary to com bine aad fuse a pore silioo alkaline glaze. Tin- main problem, therefore, to be solved is to diaoover a process whioh dispenses with the of lead without increasing the cost ol prodeetion. Until this is aooomplisheri, tbs saooets of the leadlest prodoote will daps: d mainly on the philanthropic motives ol customers; otherwise, nothing short of an international agreemant ooold eliminate <h» r to indnstry involve I by any measure for tba abolition of lead in the Potteries.

VENICE is a 5 hours' journey by rail from Milan, and one of tho most delightful places imaginable to pass a u ict stay. Tho total absence of vehic-lar traffic strikes one *s very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicyclo is to be seen, ami yet there is tho sound of life at every, turn. The approach the Venice from tho Adriatic is jm'ike that of any other seaport The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of tho »ca, no hills behind, no stretches "f rock, but first tho top* of Campanile* appear above the horizon, then sl-wly tho whole glittering towu rises like a fairy mirage out of the cairn lagoon.
(ioing northwards from Mi'an you make the tour of the bea- tifal Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reach'-d in one and-a quarter hours by tram by way of Monza :
Boats leave Como frequently for tho othor towi)* on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery «n either side going "p the lake is most ench riling CKRNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menagglo with the prettily-situated town of HtUaggio opposite. The walk from Tremrzzo along tho shore of the lako to Menaggio is most enjoyable A steam tram r-ns from M-nagg'to to Pialezza on Iziko Lugano in three-quarters ot sn hour, then steamer to Lugano in twoand- three quarter hours. ,
